snippet: Swedes rejected austerity and tax-cutting policies that many feared threaten their cherished social-welfare system. At the same time, a far-right party gained substantial ground.
abstract: Left-leaning parties win slim but clear lead in Sweden's parliamentary elections, bringing country closer to center left after eight years of tax-cutting and free-market government; Sweden's far-right democrats become third force in country's politics, doubling their share of vote to 13 percent and setting stage to hold balance of power.
lead_paragraph: Swedes rejected austerity and tax-cutting policies that many feared threaten their cherished social-welfare system. At the same time, a far-right party gained substantial ground.

headline.main: Sweden Takes a Left Turn After 8 Years of Rightist Rule
headline.print_headline: Sweden Takes a Left Turn After 8 Years of Rightist Rule
